instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flux All Over The Board, No Power
threads.message:
Hello. Got this rabbit hole from hell here with no power. Charger negotiates 5V on all ports. Around 250mA power draw on all ports. Machine enters DFU, but does not complete restore neither revive option. Board has been well poked around by another store and it got flux on the whole board, including around T2 chip (shit!). I think maybe they killed T2 with heat.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.25V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 1.18V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>I2C_UPC_XA_DBG_CTL_SCL</SIGNAL> - 3.34V
<SIGNAL>I2C_UPC_XA_DBG_CTL_SDA</SIGNAL> - 3.34V
<SIGNAL>PHV_INT_XA_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> - 3.34V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.34V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flux All Over The Board, No Power
threads.message:
Do you have all SSD voltages present?

Is probably time wasting, other service may have removed components, or made more damage on the board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flux All Over The Board, No Power
threads.message:
Will post everything with SSD on name:

<SIGNAL>HS_P3V3_G3W_SSD0_OUT</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>HS_P3V3_G3W_SSD1_OUT</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>HS_PBUS_MAIN_SSD0_OUT</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>HS_PBUS_MAIN_SSD1_OUT</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>I2C_SSD0_SCL</SIGNAL> = 1,8V
<SIGNAL>I2C_SSD0_SDA</SIGNAL> = 1,8V

<SIGNAL>I2C_SSD1_SCL</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>I2C_SSD_SCL</SIGNAL> = 1,8V
<SIGNAL>I2C_SSD0_SDA</SIGNAL> = 1,8V
<SIGNAL>ISNS_P3V3_G3W_SSD0_N</SIGNAL> = 3,3V
<SIGNAL>ISNS_P3V3_G3W_SSD0_P</SIGNAL> = 3,3V

<SIGNAL>ISNS_P3V3_G3W_SSD0_P</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>ISNS_PBUS_MAIN_SSD0_N</SIGNAL> = 12,25V
<SIGNAL>ISNS_PBUS_MAIN_SSD0_P</SIGNAL> = 12,25V
<SIGNAL>P0V9_LX0_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>P1V8_LX0_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>P0V9_LX1_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>P2V5_SW2_TPS62180_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flux All Over The Board, No Power
threads.message:
DFU can't be completed if no SSD voltages present.
Dig around <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>/80.
Check diode mode to ground at L9020/30/80.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flux All Over The Board, No Power
threads.message:
Hello. I'm suspecting <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> is bad, because I have some voltages around it, but it seems not to be outputting expected signals... I have:

<SIGNAL>SSD0_OCARINA_FORCE_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_OCARINA_IREF</SIGNAL> = 1,130V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_OCARINA_VDD_LDO</SIGNAL> = 1,5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SSD0_SNS</SIGNAL> = 3,3V

Diode mode on coils:

L9020 = 0,165
L9030 = 0,320
L9080 = 0,338

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flux All Over The Board, No Power
threads.message:
You can use a T2 power on sequence from available boards; 01598 and 01055 must be somewhere on the forum.
And check the previous signals required by SSD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flux All Over The Board, No Power
threads.message:
I'm following this power sequence diagram: [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/CD3217_and_T2_Power_on_Sequence[/URL]

I have all voltages up to <SIGNAL>PCH_RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>. From <SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> forward I have nothing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Flux All Over The Board, No Power
threads.message:
DFU revive should solve the power on sequence, if btoken because of T2 firmware corruption.
Seems that you have problems with secondary power supplies, or T2 with internal problem.

<SIGNAL>P3V3MAIN_PGOOD</SIGNAL> comes high?
